loans.name: Zaitun

texts.en:
Zaitun is a married woman with five children, two of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

For the past four years, she has operated a food stall business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. Her greatest monthly expense is competition from other food stall operators. She dreams of expanding her business to meet her customers' needs.

With the KSHS 20,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and rice for her food stall. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and rice for her food stall.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman who owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Fatuma operates a retail shop business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. In addition she also operates a farming business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the Kshs 50,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, rice and potatoes. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, rice and potatoes.

loans.name: Armando

texts.es: El señor Armando nacido en Chuquisaca casado con la Sra. Paulina ella se dedica a labores del hogar, tienen 4 hijos todos pequeños, ellos tienen su parcela en Santo Corazón a 6 km de Limoncito donde viven y trabajan en la agricultura, el siembra maní, yuca, maíz, y sorgo para fabricas de escobas. Todo lo que el produce lo comercializa en el mercado del Torno, el destino del crédito es para la compra de semilla para siembra de maní y yuca, hace unos 8 años que se dedica a esta actividad, donde le va muy bien, es una persona muy trabajadora agradecido con la institución por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en: Armando was born in Chuquisaca and is married to Ms. Paulina, who takes care of their household duties. The have four children who are all young. They have a parcel of land in Santo Corazón, 6 kilometers from Limoncito, where they live and work in agriculture. Armando plants peanuts, yucca, corn, and sorghum for making brooms. He sells everything that he produces in the Torno market. This loan will be used to buy seeds for planting peanuts and yucca. He has been doing this work for eight years and it is going very well. He is a very hard-working person and is grateful for the support he is being offered.

loans.use: to buy peanut and yucca seeds

loans.name: Saadiyeh

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. She is 40 years old, married and has five children. Three of her children work.

Saadiya has been a tailor since 2007. She makes and repairs women’s clothing. She has a deep understanding of local consumer needs, a good reputation and is well known in her area.
 
She is requesting a $2,400 loan to buy a generator and an embroidery machine. She is aiming to gain more profits so she can improve her family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To buy a generator and an embroidery machine.

loans.name: Koeprieng

texts.en:
Koeprieng (pictured above) is 28 years old and her husband, Sung is 30 years old.  They live across the Mekong River, about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.  They have been married since 2003 and have two young children, one son and one daughter.

Koeprieng sells fish that her husband catches.  She also buys additional fish from other fisherman and sells them in the local market.  Her husband is a fisherman and farmer.  Koeprieng is asking for a loan of $800 to purchase a motorcycle to carry fish to the market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to carry fish to the market.

loans.name: Mariamu

texts.en:
Mariamu is a single woman with one child who graduated from school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, clothing and electricity bills.

For the past seven years, she has operated a business selling palm wine, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. In addition, she sells charcoal, which contributes to her other source of income. She faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation in her business. Mariamu dreams of furnishing her house in the future.

With the KSHS 40,000, she wants to purchase ten sacks of charcoal and pay for transport. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase 10 sacks of charcoal and pay for transport.

loans.name: Concepción De María

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Managua, la señora Concepción De María es una persona trabajadora de buenos valores morales  que se dedica arduamente a laborar en circulación bibliotecaria y se dedica a esta labor desde hace veintitrés años. Es soltera y tiene cinco persona a su cargo.

Actualmente ha acudido a Ceprodel con el fin de solicitar un crédito para mejorar la condición de su vivienda en la compra de materiales de construcción tales como bloque, cemento, hierro y pago de mano de obra, para construir baño en su vivienda, así brindarle una condición mejor a su familia, este es el primer crédito con Ceprodel para dale un mejor nivel  de vida a su familia.
texts.en:
Concepción De María lives in Managua, and she is a hardworking woman of good moral values. She works in a library as circulation technician, a job she has been laboriously doing for twenty-three years. She is single with five people in her care.

She has come to CEPRODEL to ask for a loan she will use to improve the conditions of her house. She will buy construction materials such as blocks, cement and iron, as well as to pay for labor costs. She will have a bathroom built in her house to offer belter living condition to her family. This is the first loan she has requested to CEPRODEL to give a better standard of living to her family.

loans.use: To buy construction materials and to pay for labor costs.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is 43 years old and lives in Dumagoc, Pagadian City. She is married and has three children.

Virginia has an business outlet where she sells fish. She has had this business for 2 years. She has requested a loan to add additional capital to her business.

Virginia has been a member of Paglaum Multi-purpose cooperative for 4 years.

loans.use: to add addtional capital to her existing business.

loans.name: Aiden

texts.en:
This is Aiden.  She is 38 years old and is a resident of Tanza, Cavite City, Philippines. Her husband is Benjamin, a security guard.  Aiden is a mother of three children, two are studying in elementary school while one is still staying at home. She, together with her children, manages their own household while operating her business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Aiden operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, PHP5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and  people in the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 350 in sales every day.  Aside from this, Aiden also sews rugs for added income. 

To help continue the operations of her business, Aiden is requesting a loan of Php 10,000. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products needed in her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Aiden hopes to be able to expand soon and dreams of being able to give her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy grocery items

loans.name: Estrellita

texts.en:
Estrellita is 33 years old and lives in Nagbukel San Isidro. She is married and blessed with two children. She has been a public servant and has been running her sari-sari (general store) for five years. Estrellita sells different kinds of basic products, such as sugar, salt, cooking oil, soy sauce, snack food, and other items. Aside from the grocery store, she runs a direct-selling business, wherein she offers cosmetic products, lotions, and perfumes. Estrellita's business is a great help to her family to sustain their daily needs.

She is requesting a loan amounting to 18,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to purchase additional goods to sell in her general store, such as ingredients, candies, biscuits, and soft drinks. She has a great plan for her future and for the family, to increase her profit and expand her store. She hopes that she can make all her dreams come true through her hard work and patience in managing her business.

loans.use: to purchase groceries such as ingredients, candies, biscuits, and soft drinks to sell in her general store

loans.name: Anielka Elizabeth

texts.es: La señora Anielka Elizabeth tiene 23 años, es madre soltera y con mucho sacrificio ha sacado adelante a su hijo de 3 años. Tiene su actividad que es una pulpería, desde hace mas 3 años es una mujer trabajadora y gracias a su esfuerzo tiene todos lo que posee hasta los momentos. El financiamiento es para la compra de leche, huevos, arroz, frijoles, aceite, galletas, sopas, enlatados y fideos. Desea comprar más productos para así vender más y obtener mejores ganancias.
texts.en: Anielka Elizabeth, 23, is a single mother.  With much sacrifice she’s managed to support her 3-year-old son.  She has had a grocery store for three years.  She’s a hardworking woman and thanks to her efforts she has everything she owns to date.  The loan is to buy milk, eggs, rice, beans, oil, cookies, soup, canned goods and pasta.  She wants to buy more products to sell more and earn better profits.

loans.use: to buy stock merchandise for her store.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 58 years old and married with 7 children aged 17-40 living in his own house in Hioma, Uganda. He has dependents and he is the only income earner in the family.

For two years he has been running a business of house renting and this has facilitated him in providing for his family. He started as a motor vehicle stage guide and after saving enough of his wages he started to build the house that he is renting out. He hopes to construct more houses in the future to rent. John needs the loan to renovate his house.

loans.use: to renovate his house.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to provide maintenance to his mototaxi

loans.name: Claudia

texts.es:
Claudia nació en la  ciudad de Urubamba provincia de Urubamba del departamento del Cusco y ahora vive en la misma ciudad donde nació, ella tiene 56 años de edad y es casada y fruto de esta unión tiene cuatro hijos.
 
Claudia desarrolla sus actividades cotidianas y económicas en la ciudad de Urubamba, ella es proveedora de materiales de construcción en la ciudad de Urubamba. Ya son siete años que se dedica a este negocio y le va muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo. 

Claudia requiere el préstamo para comprar mas mercadería como por ejemplo arena, cemento, piedra chancada y otras cosas más.  

Claudia se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma. Claudia pertenece al banco comunal “Tercer Milenio” de la Asociación Arariwa de la ciudad de Urubamba.
texts.en:
Claudia, 56, was born in Urubamba, a city in the Peruvian "departamento" of Cusco.  She still lives there with her husband and their four children.
 
Claudia owns a construction materials sales business in Urubamba.  She has operated the business for seven years and has worked hard to make it a success.

Claudia wants a loan to buy merchandise--sand, cement, and gravel, for example--that she will resell.

Claudia is grateful for the opportunities that this type of lending provides and is committed to repaying her loan in the agreed-upon time.  She belongs to the Tercer Milenio community bank, an Asociacion Arariwa partner in Urubamba.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for construction materials business.

loans.name: Hasan

texts.en: Hasan is  23 years old, single and lives with his parents and one sibling. His father works for the local municipality while Husan earns a living selling car accessories in a shop he opened in 2007. He also works on the side as a barber in a salon he owns. He is applying for a loan for $1,100 from Kiva partner Ameen to buy more car accessories to sell to his customers. He believes that this loan will allow him to improve his business and increase his profits. His goal for the future is to expand his car accessories shop.

loans.use: to buy new car accessories to sell to his customers.

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida is a 49-year-old married woman from Talibon, Bohol. She has a 27-year-old child.

Zenaida has been in the business of raising hogs for 4 years. She earns 7000 PHP with this business. Zenaida also runs a small sari-sari store where she sells canned goods, shampoo, soap and other items. Zenaida works hard to support her family.

Zenaida is requesting a loan to buy pig feed and more items to sell, like canned goods and instant noodles. She hopes for her businesses to grow.

loans.use: to buy pig feed and more items to sell like canned goods and instant noodles.

loans.name: God Bless Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “God Bless” group. They are small scale businesswomen based in Makeni, a city in Northern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Isatu. Isatu is 36 years old. She was born in Makeni where she is currently residing together with her husband and five children. Her husband is a military officer and her children are attending primary, secondary and tertiary institutions. For five years now, she has been selling market-food such as palm oil, rice, etc. With the help of this loan, she will buy gallons of palm oil and bags of rice to add to her market's inventory.

loans.use: to buy gallons of palm oil and bags of rice to add to her business

loans.name: Virginia

texts.es: Virginia de 64 años es una mujer muy trabajadora es viuda y vive con alguno de sus hijos, la mayor parte del día se la pasa en su trabajo que se trata de elaborar pasteles de diferente estilos y sabores, desde hace 21 años, aparte recibe pensión por viudez el cual le ayuda a cubrir todos sus gastos. En este momento quiere un préstamo para comprar pintura y remodelar su casa por dentro ya que con las inclemencias del tiempo las paredes están muy dañadas por  lo que quiere preparase antes de que se deterioren aun mas.
texts.en:
Virginia is 64, and a very hard-working woman. She is a widow, and lives with one of her children. 

She spends most of her day at her work, making cakes of different designs and flavors, which she has been doing for 21 years. Apart from this, she gets a widow's pension, which helps her cover all her expenses. 

At this time, she wants a loan to buy paint and remodel her home on the inside, as with the inclement weather, the walls are quite damaged, so she wants to take steps before they deteriorate even more.

loans.use: To buy paint for her house.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is 53 years old, married and has 5 children.  He works as a solar lamp distributor in Mali.

Prior to becoming a distributor for NOTS, Daniel studied agriculture and engineering and worked as a farm manager at a Malian textile company.   Upon learning about the work of NOTS Mali, he was very motivated to become a distributor because he knew solar lamps would be a great benefit to people living in the rural areas where he lived and worked.  

Daniel sells solar lamps directly to farmers and through small retailers and individual entrepreneurs in Sikasso, the southern-most region in Mali.   Most people living in this area work in agriculture and about 80% of the population does not have access to electricity.  They rely, instead, on kerosene, flashlights and candles for light and they must walk long distances and pay to charge their mobile phones.  On top of being harmful to the environment, time-consuming, and damaging to users health (inhaling kerosene fumes is like smoking 2 packs of cigarettes a day), these energy sources are expensive, costing a family about $110 per year - $80 for kerosene and $30 to charge a mobile phone.   

A solar lamp that provides up to 16 hours of light, can charge a mobile phone and has a lifetime of about 5 years costs just $35.  Purchasing a solar lamp is a win-win - families benefit because they save time, money and they are safer and healthier and the environment benefits from less toxic waste and reduced CO2 emissions caused by kerosene use.  

The funds from Kiva investors will allow Daniel to purchase 570 solar lamps and sell them to cotton and sesame farmers on credit.  These lamps will impact almost 4,000 lives.  Harvest season starts in September, so it is a good time for Daniel to sell lamps as the farmers will have some money to pay for the lamps.  It is difficult, however, for them to pay in one lump-sum payment, so Daniel will collect payments in installments.  This way farmers can access solar light without so much financial strain on their household.

loans.use: To buy solar lamps that he will sell to cotton and sesame farmers.

loans.name: Soeurng's Group

texts.en: Soeurng,40, is a local famer residing in Battambang province.  Her main sources of income are from rice cropping. She supplements her family’s income via her paid-working job. This is the second loan for Soeurng with VisionFund(Kiva’s partner). She has repaid back her past loan wisely and it has improved her lifestyle gradually. Now, in a group of two, she is a leader. For Soeurng, she will use this loan to pay for plowing fee for her farmland. She hopes this loan will enable her to prepare her farmland seasonably so as she can replanting her crop and get a good yield.

loans.use: To pay for plowing fee for her farmland

loans.name: Thao

texts.en: Mrs. Thao is 61 years old,  has two children. She has always earned her living in agriculture and livestock raising alongside her family who taught her these skills. For some months now she has had her own pigs to raise and fatten and then sell in various parts of town.Her goal is to increase the number of pigs she is raising. She is seeking a loan to buy several pigs and the feed she requires to raise them. The money she earns from expanding her business will increase and she will be able to have a better standard of living with no financial problems. Her two children depend on the success of her business. Her greatest dream is to have a house of her own and improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To buy several pigs and the feed she requires to raise them

loans.name: Eduardo Alonso

texts.en:
My name is Eduardo B., I have a shop located next to the highway that goes to the city, for five years I have provided services such as tire repair, I also buy second-hand tires and sell them as spare tires. With my earnings, I support my family of three children, all of whom are in school.

Descripción del Negocio: Me llamo Eduardo B., tengo un taller ubicado a la orilla de la carretera hacia la ciudad, desde hace cinco años doy el servicio de reparación de llantas, también compro de segunda para venderlas como llanta de repuestos. Con las ganancias que obtengo sostengo a mi familia de tres hijos los cuales están en la escuela.

loans.use: Lubricants, tires, products to repair tires.

loans.name: Aklobessi

texts.en:
Mrs. Aklobessi G. is a 50-year old widow. She is the mother of seven (07) children and also takes care of three (03) additional children. She has a lot of experience in weaving mats and specializes in the dying of straw to decorate these mats. Thanks to her mat-braiding skills, she is able to support all her children. The quality of her work, well done and delivered on time, has made her very well-known and respected. Currently, she has gained the confidence of her clients, who regulary request her services. But she needs lots of material to satisfy all of these increasingly urgent demands. This is why she is asking for a loan of $650 to obtain raffia, straw, and dye to respond to the many requests of her clientele. The benefits drawn from this business will allow her to meet the needs of her children and her whole family.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer.

Madame G. Aklobessi est une femme veuve âgée de 50 ans Elle est mère de sept (07) enfants et a à sa charge trois (03) autres enfants. Elle a beaucoup d’expériences dans le tressage des nattes et est spécialisée dans la teinture des pailles pour la décoration des nattes. C’est grâce au tressage de nattes qu’elle a supporté tous ses enfants. La qualité de son travail bien fait et rendu à temps ont fait d’elle une femme de très bonne renommée et très respectée. Actuellement, elle a gagné la confiance des clients qui sollicitent régulièrement ses services. Mais il lui faut beaucoup de moyens pour satisfaire à toutes ces demandes de plus en plus importantes. C’est pourquoi elle sollicite un crédit de $650 pour se procurer les raphias, les pailles et les teintures pour répondre aux nombreuses exigences de sa clientèle. Les bénéfices tirés de commerce permettront de subvenir convenablement aux besoins de ses enfants et de toute la famille.

loans.use: To procure raffia, straw, and dye for weaving mats

loans.name: Roberto

texts.en:
Roberto has run a small business out his house for 3 years now. "I need to buy more merchandise and 2 pieces of furniture in which to display the products I sell. The fact is, my house is very small and I would also like to enlarge my store a bit, to have more space and to be able to offer more products for sale". He is applying for a loan of $1000 with which to buy merchandise, enlarge the store, and buy the 2 pieces of furniture in which to display his products.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

El Sr. Roberto tiene un pequeño negocio en su casa desde hace 3 años. “Necesito comprar más mercancía y 2 muebles para acomodar las cosas que vendo, en realidad mi casa es muy chica y también me gustaría ampliar un poco hacia adelante mi negocio para tener más espacio y poder poner más cosas en venta”. Solicito $ 1,000.00 dlls para comprar mercancía, hacer más amplio mi negocio y también compra 2 muebles.

loans.use: Buy merchandise and 2 wooden pieces of furniture for product display, and enlarge the store.

loans.name: Iris Amador

texts.en:
Iris is determined to start working on selling various tropical fruits as a start to her own business. She plans to start off buying fruits at the “people’s central market” and bring them with a hired transport to her market area. She is presently living with her husband and three children, two boys and one girl.

For the time being, Iris is assisting the family’s economic needs by working three days a week as a maid in a private residence at the capital city of Santo Domingo. This means she has to take public transportation to get to work. Just this factor takes a 25% toll from her precious USD$100.00 (approximate equivalent) a month salary. She lives in the northern part of Santo Domingo, in an a populous area called Los Alcarrizos, in the community of Barrio Paraiso, where she has lived for 12 years now.

loans.use: To start her fruit selling stand by buying fruits at the market

loans.name: Aziza

texts.en:
Aziza M. has been engaged in business for the past six years. Aziza  is married and has five children. Her husband is in Russia, where he went to earn money. Her children go to school. 
Her business is to sell household goods and she has her own canteens in Chkalovsk, Khujand. She employs one seller for her business of selling household goods.(He is in the photo). Aziza buys her goods from Istaravshan. Her assortment of inventory consists of such goods as sieves, spoons and ladles. Gradually she plans to increase the number of her goods to sell and with that profit she plans to rent a little shop to sell her goods. She want to receive a loan of $400 for four months.

loans.use: Purchase  of next batch of goods.

loans.name: Halimah

texts.en:
Halimah is 38 years of age, is married, and has four children. She is a businesswoman operating a beauty salon in the Kampala suburb, styling hair for ladies.

In her family of five, the eldest daughter is a university student aged 20; the other three girls are aged 16,14, and 10. There is only one boy in the family, aged 13, going for secondary education. Halimah has been in the salon business for the last eight years, and it has helped her provide school fees for her family.

She is requesting to borrow $1,100 to purchase new salon equipment: a steamer, hair dryers, and cosmetics. With the increase in equipment, Halimah is optimistic that the number of customers will greatly increase, so she will realize bigger profits. That will allow her to continue paying school fees for her children, whose education has become increasingly expensive.

loans.use: To purchase salon equipment (hair dryer and steamer) and cosmetics

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
After hearing about the widely publicized activities of the TYM, Mrs. Nguyen Thi D., thirty-nine years old, thought that taking a loan and paying it back weekly would be manegeable for her family. She discused with her family and her husband, Mr. Pham Van Tuan approved for her to go ahead. From a small start-up capital, she dared to open a litle grocery store. Being a skillful, attractive lady with nice personality, she has more and more customers coming to her store. She is anxious to expand the business and carry more merchandises. She requests for a loan of $US 450 to buy wine, beer ,candies, cookies to sell to the community in the upcoming lunar New Year (Tet).

Translated from Vietnamese by a Kiva volunteer.

Sau khi nghe tuyên truyền về hoạt động của Quỹ Tình thương, chị Nguyễn Thị Đông, 39 tuổi, nhận thấy việc vay vốn hoàn trả tuần rất phù hợp với gia đình mình. Chị đã bàn bạc với gia đình và nhận được sự ủng hộ của chồng, anh Phạm Văn Tuấn. Từ nguồn vốn ban đầu rất ít ỏi chị đã mạnh dạn mở quầy hàng để bán. Là ngưòi phụ nữ khéo léo đẹp người đẹp nết nên hàng chị ngày càng đông khách. Cửa hàng của chị làm ăn phát triển nên việc đầu tư thêm hàng hoá và sửa sang cửa hàng được chị rất chú trọng. Vòng vốn này chị Đông đề nghị vay 450USD để mua thêm hàng bia rượu bánh kẹo phục vụ bà con trong dịp Tết..

loans.use: Buy wine, confectionary for her grocery store

loans.name: Dino Salvador

texts.es:
Mr M.'s business is the creation and sale of necklaces, bracelets and hoop earrings which he sells in different places such as markets and in celebrations such as fairs in his town. It has taken him 7 years to build his business with an initial sum of C$3,000.00 (Nicaraguan córdoba), which was an inheritance from his parents and grandparents.

He began his travelling business with the sale of costume jewellery (hoop earrings, bracelets and necklaces) and according to the season he would sell his products. Today he sells his products in the main street where there is a steady flow of customers, making this a fairly dynamic but very tired business given that it is exposed to the sun all day.

In order to support Mr M.’s situation, Ceprodel provided him with financial support a year and a half ago, granting him 8 loans, which have had a direct impact on his business, increasing his sales which in turn allow him to support his family and continue creating and selling his products.

Translated from Spanish by Lucy Williams, Kiva Translator

El negocio al cual se dedica el señor M. es a la elaboración y venta de collares, pulseras y aretes que vende en diferentes lugares como mercados y en actividades de festejos como ferias en su municipio. Tiene 7 años de tener el negocio con un monto inicial de C$ 3.000.00 producto de una herencia obtenida de sus padres y abuelos.

Inició su negocio ambulante con la venta de bisuterías (aretes, pulseras, collares) y según la temporada vendía sus productos. Actualmente vende en la calle principal en donde hay mucha afluencia de clientes siendo este un negocio bastante dinámico pero muy cansado por el hecho de que debe de exponerse al sol todo el día.

Para poder apoyar la situación del señor M. Ceprodel le brindó apoyo financiero desde hace año y medio habiéndosele otorgado 8 créditos, los que han impactado de manera directa incrementando sus ventas para poder así sustentar su hogar y continuar con la elaboración y venta de sus productos.

loans.use: To purchase materials

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
Juana works breeding dairy cattle, she commercializes milk to Andina PIL (Milk Possessing Plant). She lives with her two small children and husband in the Community of Ninachiri, Laca areathree and three an half hours from the city of La Paz. Her husband is a baker in their community and his income helps to support their family. The loan will use to buy improved race dairy cattle and this way increase the milk production. This is the second loan with Impro. The evaluation made qualifies her to grant her the loan. The previous loan was completely repaid.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva Volunteer.

Juana se dedica a la crianza de ganado vacuno, cuya producción de leche comercializa a PIL Andina (Planta Industrializadota de Leche). Vive en la Comunidad de Ninachiri sector Laja a tres horas y media de la ciudad de La Paz, junto a sus dos pequeños hijos y su esposo el cual es panadero de la comunidad con cuyos ingresos ayuda en el sostenimiento de la familia. El crédito lo destinara para la compra de ganado de raza mejorada y así incrementar la producción de leche. Es el segundo crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada le califica para otorgarle el préstamo. El préstamo anterior fue cancelado en su totalidad.

loans.use: Buy improved race dairy cattle.

loans.name: Edelmira Teodora

texts.es:
Edelmira Teodora A. Castillo is 54 years old and has 6 children who depend on her.

Her business is buying men's and women's clothing which she then sells on Sundays in different hamlets.

She lives in the Cuyuchugo hamlet in the Usquíl district of Otuzco province in the department of La Libertad.

She's had an entrepreneurial spirit since she was 18 years old, offering a few products to her community. When she started, she made her income by selling fruits and vegetables and was able to save up her money.

Edelmira is part of Banco Comunal "San Juan de Miraflores" and received her first loan of 300 soles (3 soles = $1) which she used to buy wholsesale clothing and fabrics to make aprons, skirts and tablecloths.

With the loan of 2500 soles, that she will repay in full in 4 months, she'll buy 20 meters of fabric and thread, as well as, shirts, sweaters and pants that she will sell later.

Her ideal would be to have a store in her home.

Translated by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Edelmira Teodora A. Castillo tiene 54 años de edad, estudió primaria completa. Tiene 6 hijos que aún dependen de ella. El negocio al que se dedica es la compra y venta de ropa para damas y caballeros los que vende los días sábados por los diferentes caseríos. Vive en el caserío de Cuyuchugo distrito de Usquíl, provincia de Otuzco, departamento de La Libertad. Desde que tenia 18 años tuvo la idea de ofrecer algunos productos por su comunidad, empezó vendiendo frutas y verduras, las ganancias que obtenía las iba ahorrando, de esa manera hizo su propio capital. Ella integra el Banco Comunal “San Juan de Miraflores” del cual recibió su primer préstamo de S/. 300.00, con este dinero compró ropa al por mayor y telas para confeccionar algunas prendas tales como: mandiles, faldas, y manteles. Con el préstamo de S/. 2500.00 que cancelará en cuatro meses, comprará 20 metros de tela e hilos, asimismo comprará camisas, chompas y pantalones para posteriormente venderlos. La señora Edelmira fue fiscal del comedor de su caserío “Santísima Trinidad”, actualmente se mantiene como socia. Su ideal es poner una tienda en su vivienda.

loans.use: To buy fabrics and thread, as well as, shirts, sweaters and pants.

loans.name: Hoang Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs Hoàng Thị Cù is 60 years old. She is one of the most active members and an exemplary entrepreneur of TYM, branch Phúc Yên. In 1999 when TYM opened Phúc Yên branch, she was the first to join. She also encouraged her daughter and daughters in law to do the same. Today there are 4 members from her family who are TYM members, their loans from TYM range from 700 to 1200 USD which are well invested. Since her house is well located, Mrs Cù has opened a store selling pop soda, cookies, snacks and also grocery. Her business is stable and it provides her with cash flow. Every time the loans officers come to visit her, they are always greeted warmly. Her husband is very supportive of her and encourages his children. Their wish is to remain TYM member for a long time to come, to be qualified for bigger loan so that they can expand their business and increase their revenue. This time Mrs Cù is requesting a loan of 1200 USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Hoàng Thị Cù, 60 tuổi, là một trong những thành viên tích cực, điển hình của chi nhánh Phúc Yên. Năm 1999 khi Quỹ về địa phương chị là người hăng hái tham gia đầu tiên, ngoài ra chị còn vận động con gái, con dâu cùng tham gia vào Quỹ. Hiện nay gia đình chị có 4 người là thành viên của cụm và đều vay vốn lớn từ 700 đến 1200USD, sử dụng đúng mục đích và cho thu nhập cao. Với địa thế nhà gần đường thuận lợi cho việc kinh doanh buôn bán, chị Cù đầu tư vào các mặt hàng bánh kẹo, nước giải khát và các hàng hoá sinh hoạt khác. Công việc của chị cho thu nhập rất ổn định hàng ngày. Mỗi lần đến thăm chị và gia đình, chúng tôi đều được đón tiếp với một thái độ cởi mở, thân thiết. Chồng chị là người rất am hiểu về Quỹ và luôn ủng hộ tạo điều kiện cho vợ và các con cùng tham gia. Tâm sự của họ là sẽ tham gia Quỹ lâu dài để tiếp tục vay vốn lớn hơn phát triển kinh tế gia đình. Vòng vốn này chị Cù xin vay 1200USD mua thêm hàng về bán.

loans.use: Buy goods for her grocery store

loans.name: Celine

texts.en: Celine N. is business-focused and very determined to increase her business and to lift her family above poverty. Celine is 35 years of age, with a kid; she lives in Jakunde community, Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells provisions, foodstuffs and drinks in her neighborhood. She also has two drums that she uses for storing her provisions at night to prevent insects and rats from destroying them. She has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 2 years and now needs a loan of $875 to enable her to buy more provisions, foodstuffs, and drinks for her inventory.

loans.use: To buy provisions, foodstuffs, and drinks for re-sale

loans.name: Kosar

texts.en: Kosar lives in district 8 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is single. He supports his family with a retail shop.  He started his business one year ago.  The location of his shop is good; day by day he attracts more clients.  He needs to complete his stock so he wants to take an individual loan.  This will help him to improve his business, help his family and make a better future for himself.  He is happy about this loan process.

loans.use: To improve his business

loans.name: Francisco Oscar

texts.es:
"For more than a year, my wife and I have been working in this business. The business is selling women's and men's shoes. But we also want to sell shoes for children and we do not have enough money stock our business without using equity. For this reason we are requesting a loan for $1,200 dollars, in order to buy children´s shoes."

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva volunteer.

Tenemos ya mas de 1 años con el negocio en el trabajamos mi esposa y yo. El negocio es venta de calzado para dama y caballero. Pero también queremos vender calzado para niños y nos esta haciendo falta capital para surtir el negocio sin descapitalizarlo. Es por eso que solicitamos un préstamo de $ 1,200.00 Dlls. Para la comprar de Calzado para niños.

loans.use: Buy merchandise.

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.es:
Ofelia is a very active woman who, through her communication skills, tries to relate to people to create situations that benefit the sale of her agricultural products. The production of citrus fruits is what she most likes and makes her feel content in addition to being the principal generator of income for her home. However, one of her limitations that is developing rapidly is a problem with her health. Ofelia suffers from asthma which limits her from doing certain activities. But, without doubt, she is a very optimistic woman who struggles to keep this from harming her production and, thanks to God, until now, she has been able to work adequately. Because of a rise in the price of fertilizers, she is asking for a loan, money that will give her the opportunity to improve and maintain her production adequately.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer.

Ofelia es una mujer muy activa que por su capacidad de comunicación trata de relacionarse con las personas para abrir espacios que favorezcan la mejora de la venta de sus productos agrícolas.La producción de frutos cítricos es lo que más le gusta y la hace sentir contenta, además de ser el principal generador de ingresos en su hogar. Sin embargo una de sus limitaciones para desenvolverse con rapidez es su problema de salud, Ofelia sufre de asma, lo que la limita para realizar ciertas actividades, pero sin duda es una mujer muy optimista que lucha por que esto no perjudique su producción y gracias a Dios hasta hoy a podido trabajar adecuadamente.Debido a la alza de los precios de los abonos solicita un préstamo, dinero que le dará la posibilidad de mejorar y mantener su producción adecuadamente.

loans.use: The Purchase of Fertilizer for her Fruit Fields

loans.name: Kayi

texts.fr:
Née en 1970 à Aklakou au TOGO, Madame A. Kayi est spécialisée dans le stockage de céréales en période d’abondance et de leur revendre en temps de soudure depuis 15 ans. Cette activité très rentable lui permet de contribuer efficacement à la charge du ménage.

Face à l’augmentation des besoins de sa famille, elle est soucieuse d’assurer un avenir meilleur à ses deux enfants, se propose d’augmenter son stock afin d’accroître son bénéfice. 

Pour ce faire, elle sollicite un crédit qui lui servira de fonds de roulement indispensable à la sécurisation et à la consistance de son revenu .
texts.en:
Born in 1970 in the village of Aklakou in Togo, for 15 years Kayi A. has specialized in stockpiling grain in season for resale in the off-season. This very profitable business permits her to effectively contribute to household expenses. With the increasing needs of her family, she is anxious to ensure a better future for her two children, and proposes to augment her inventory with the goal of increasing profits. To do so, she is requesting a loan to provide the necessary working capital to guarantee a steady income.

Translated from French by Joyce K., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stockpiling and resale of grain

loans.name: Atsu

texts.fr:
Monsieur N. est né à Tchébébé en 1968. Il est secrétaire dactylographe en chômage. Etant marié et père de deux enfants et pour faire face aux nombreuses charges familiales, il s’est lancé dans la vente de pétrole et de potasse.
Depuis 2006 qu’il a commencé cette activité il a connu une évolution.
Il a reçu une commande de 300l de pétrole, ce qui le pousse à prendre ce crédit pour satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Mr. N. was born in Tchébébé in 1968. He is an unemployed secretarial typist. Being married and the father of two children, and to address numerous family responsibilities, he started selling kerosene and potash. Since 2006, when he began this business, he has experienced improvements. He has received an order for 300 liters of kerosene, which drives him to take out this loan to satisfy his customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy kerosene

loans.name: Domitila

texts.es:
La Señora Domitila es socia del Banco Comunal “Virgen del Rosario”, vive en la región y  provincia y distrito de Bellavista. Se dedica a la venta de abarrotes desde hace 4 años y esta muy contenta. El negocio está ubicado en su propia casa en el Jr. Tarapoto Nº 504. Sus clientes son mayormente los vecinos de su  barrio.

Con este préstamo de S/.800, el cual será cancelado en 6  meses, comprará  productos de primera necesidad como arroz, azúcar en saco, leche, aceite, conservas en cajas de diferentes tamaños, así como juguetes, papel higiénico en paquetes, detergentes, jabones de diferentes marcas y tamaños, entre otros, para poder surtir bien su negocio y que sus clientes encuentren  lo que buscan. 

Domitila tiene 37 años de edad, es madre soltera y vive con su único hijo. Es una mujer muy  trabajadora, que quiere seguir creciendo en su negocio. Su meta  es ampliar el negocio con la venta de prendas de vestir.
texts.en:
Domitila is a member of the Our Lady of the Rosary Communal Bank and lives in the region, province, and district of Bellavista. For the past four years, she has sold groceries and she is very happy. The business is located in her home at Jr. Tarapoto Nº 504. Her neighbors are her primary customers. With this loan of $275, which she will repay in six months, she will buy products of primary necessity like rice, sugar, milk, and oil, preserved in boxes of different sizes, as well as toys, toilet paper, detergent, various brands and sizes of soap, among other things, to be able to stock her business so that her customers can find what they are looking for. Domitila is a 37 year old, single mother and lives with her only son. She is a very hard-working woman who wants to keep growing her business. Her goal is to expand her business by selling clothing.

Translated from Spanish by Amani Roland, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy products like rice, sugar, and milk, for her grocery store.

loans.name: Salimatou

texts.fr: Salimatou A. est revendeuse des objets en céramique à Atakpamé, une ville située au centre du Togo. Cette activité étant sa principale source de revenu, elle souhaite accroître sa capacité par le crédit qu’elle va bénéficier afin de faire plus de profits pour la survie de sa famille
texts.en:
Salimatou A. retails ceramic objects in Atakpamé, a city in the centre of Togo. This activity being her main source of income, she wishes to increase her sales capacity with the loan in order to make greater profits for the survival of her family.

Translated from French by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise for resale

loans.name: Evans

texts.en: Evans I. owns a video shop where he rents video CD’s and sells rechargeable phone cards to his customers; however, he makes more profit from the sale of rechargeable phone cards. He needs the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more rechargeable phone cards to sell. He is 32 years old and married with a child. He says thank you to all that make this loan possible

loans.use: To purchase more rechargeable phone cards to sell

loans.name: Yovana

texts.es:
La señorita Yovana es socia del Banco Comunal “Virgen de Cancharani” de la provincia de Puno, en el departamento de Puno. Tiene 32 años de edad, es conviviente y madre de 1 hijo. Con su primer préstamo de S/. 300 compró ropa y dulces para venderlos. Tiene casi 3 años  trabajando con el banco. Nos cuenta que es docente en Macusani de lunes a viernes.
Con este préstamo de S/.1200 que pagará en  6 cuotas comprará ropa y zapatillas para la campaña navideña.
Yovana desea continuar trabajando para construir y tener una tienda de golosinas.
texts.en:
Ms. Yovana is a member of the “Virgen de Cancharani” microfinance institute in the province and department of Puno. She is 32 years old and has a live-in partner and a son. With her first 300.00 PEN loan, she purchased clothing and candy for resale. She has been working with the microfinance institute for almost 3 years. She states that she teaches in Macusani from Monday through Friday.

With this 1,200.00 PEN loan, which will be repaid in 6 monthly installments, she will purchase clothing and shoes for the holiday season.

Yovana hopes to keep working so that she can build her own candy store.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothing and shoes for the holiday season

loans.name: Akoua

texts.fr: Cette dame a pour activité la vente de bouillie, la bouillie est une nourriture très consommée au togo pour le petit déjeuner, certains le consomment aussi les soirs. Elle fait donc ses recettes dans la matinée et aussi les soirs. Elle n’a jamais obtenu de crédit de WAGES et demande son premier crédit de 150000Fpour pouvoir acheter le sucre, la farine de maïs et le charbon qui sont indispensables dans la fabrication de bouillie. Elle est mariée et a 04 enfants, son mari est un retraité, elle aide beaucoup son qui n’a plus d’activité dans les charges du foyer.
texts.en:
This lady works selling porridge. Porridge is a dish that is frequently eaten in Togo for breakfast; some also eat it in the evening. She makes sales both morning and evening. She has never had a loan from WAGES and is requesting her first loan in the amount of 150,000 F to buy sugar, maize flour, and charcoal which are indispensable in preparing porridge. She has married and has 4 children; her husband is retired and has no business activity, so she helps him a lot in supporting the family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of corn, sugar, and charcoal

loans.name: Sinjiya Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Sinjiya sont toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 33 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent en majorité dans des familles monogames dans le quartier Sanoubougou I de la ville de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali. ).
 Elles menent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres l’achat – vente de la friperie, des tissus, du bois de chauffe,des condiments alimentaires, de l’encens et de la restauration.
Elles sont à leur premier prêt (prêt solidaire) et comptent  l’utiliser pour acheter,  une ½ balle de friperie, 1 chargement de véhicule de 10 tonnes en bois de chauffe, des ingrédients pour l’encens (parfum magnon kisèni et gueni) et des condiments alimentaires. Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Sikasso, dans les foires hebdomadaires des villages environnants, à Bamako et Bobo Dioulasso au BURKINA FASO. Les marchandises sont vendues au marché de Sikasso et dans les foires hebdomadaires des villages,  au comptant  en détail  et souvent à crédit  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 15.670FCFA par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie  investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women in the Sinjiya group are all married and average 33 years of age and 4 children. Most of them live in monogamous families in the Sanoubougou I neighborhood in the city of Sikasso, third administrative region of Mali. They run diverse businesses, which are, among others, buying and selling second-hand clothing, fabrics, firewood, food condiments, frankincense, as well as food serving.

They are seeking their first group loan (solidarity loan) and intend to use it to buy half a bale of second-hand clothing, one 10-ton truckload of firewood, ingredients for frankincense (magnon kisèni and gueni perfumes) and food condiments. The get their supplies at the market in Sikasso, at the weekly fairs in the surrounding villages, in Bamako and in Bobo Dioulasso in Burkina Faso. The goods are sold at the Sikasso market and at the weekly fairs in the villages, for cash or on credit, to a clientele comprising men and women.

They intend to turn a monthly profit of XOF 15'670 (ca US$ 31) to be used partly to pay family expenses, and partly to be invested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell second-hand clothing, firewood and food condiments

loans.name: Edith Adelada

texts.es:
R. D. R. EDITH ADELAIDA, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Almendras” con domicilio en el Jr. Manco Capac N° 323 del distrito D. Calería, tiene 65 años, 03 hijos, y es viuda.


El primer préstamo fue D. S/.300.00 Nuevos Soles, el cual invirtió en cultivo y cosecha D. una parcela D. plátano.

Con el crédito D. S/. 1,500 nuevos soles, al tener experiencia en el cultivo D. plátano, invertirá en sembrío y mantenimiento D. 2 hectáreas D. plátano y una hectárea D. yuca, el producto lo venD. en la ciudad D. Pucallpa, a conocidos y una parte al mercado.


Agradece a Manuela Ramos por facilitarle el dinero para poder invertir y subsistir, por lo tanto ella se siente muy comprometida en ser muy puntual con sus cuotas y corresponder a  la confianza que le tienen.
texts.en:
Edith Adelaida R. D. R. is a member of the "Las Almendras" community bank. She lives in the district of Calería; she is 65 years old, has three children and is a widow. Her first loan was for S/.300 soles which she used to grow and harvest a field of plantain. With this loan of S/.1,500 soles and with her experience growing plantain, she will invest in the sowing and maintenance of two hectares of plantain and one hectare of cassava. She sells her produce in the city of Pucallpa to acquaintances as well as at the market. She is grateful to Manuela Ramos for providing her with the money to invest and survive. She feels very committed to repaying her loan punctually and to repaying the trust you are showing her.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sow and maintain two hectares of plantain and one hectare of cassava.

loans.name: Happy

texts.en: Happy N. is 28 years old and married with two children. She sells foodstuffs and soup ingredients, and has been in this business for a long time. Happy is requesting a loan of 70 000 NGN to purchase more stock to sell. She sends thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and soup ingredients to sell

loans.name: Helena

texts.en:
Helena O. works as a trader in Siwdo where she cooks a local food called banku (made from fermented corn/cassava dough) and sells it along the street. She has been in business for 6 years.

She is divorced with three children and received an education through junior high school. She is responsible for paying her family’s expenses such as school fees and bills.

Helena’s loan will be used to purchase more products and ingredients which she will use in making a greater quantity of banku for selling. She hopes to use the new profits to reinvest back into her business.

loans.use: To purchase more products and ingredients for making banku

loans.name: Natividad

texts.es: Natividad es una mujer de 36 años, cuya meta es tener una mejor vida, vive en su propia casa la cual construyó con mucho esfuerzo, sabe que todos los sacrificios que hace son por tener la vida que siempre soñó. Tiene un taller de metales, en el cual realiza estructuras metálicas como triciclos, carretillas, estantes, etc, sus productos son muy solicitados debido al buen acabado que tienen, cuanta con dos trabajadores que la ayudan a cumplir con los pedidos rápidamente. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es entregar a tiempo los pedidos que le hacen, lleva 8 años en este negocio y lo que le resulta más difícil es transportar los metales desde el lugar donde los compra hasta su taller. Para el futuro, espera hacer crecer su negocio y convertirlo en uno de los talleres más importantes de Juliaca. Este es el primer préstamo de Natividad con MFP y está dispuesta a trabajar mucho para pagar todas sus cuotas a tiempo, en su banco comunal es muy alegre y responsable, motivo por el cual es muy querida por el resto de sus socias. Con los 1000 soles solicitados planea comprar más metales para fabricar más estructuras metálicas y así mejorar sus ventas.
texts.en:
Natividad is a woman of 36 years of age whose goal is to have a better life. She lives in her own home which she built with great effort. She knows that all of the sacrifices that she makes are to be able to have the life of which she has always dreamed. She has a metal workshop in which she makes metal structures such as tricycles, wheelbarrows, shelves, etc, Her products are in high demand because of the good finishing that they have. She has two workers who help her to finish the orders quickly. What she most likes about her work is to deliver the orders on time. She has been in this business for 8 years and what is most difficult for her is to transport the metals from the place where she buys them to the workshop. In the future she hopes to grow her business and make it into one of the most important workshops of Juliaca. This is Natividad's first loan with MFP and she is prepared to work hard to make all of the payments on time. In her communal bank she is very happy and responsible and this is why she is much loved by the rest of its members. With the 1000 soles requested she plans to buy more metals to build more metallic structures and through this improve her sales.

Translated from Spanish by Aimee Sostowski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of Metal

loans.name: Leonila

texts.en:
Mrs. Leonila O., 54 years of age, married, is a resident of P3 Molicay, Ozamiz City. She joined PMPC in March 2007 and was able to access her 1st loan. As the sole breadwinner of the family because of the illness of her husband, she works as a cook and all-round worker in a certain food house in the city. She also makes ice candy and sells it to their neighbors and friends in their barangay (village) to add to their family income.

Now she is applying for the amount of Php 5,000 to add to her capital in their little Sari-sari (variety) Store in their house, to be managed by her husband. Her only dream in life is to be able to establish a big Sari-sari Store in her house and be able to send her only child to school through college and find a better job.

loans.use: Additional capital for her little Sair-sari Store

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr: Aminata N., 47 ans est veuve mère de 04 enfants avec 04 autres personnes  à sa charge. Son activité est le commerce de tissus. Ce prêt va lui permettre d’acheter des tissus teintés en bazin, en khartoum et des meulfeu ( en tissu voile) pour renforcer son activité et améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Aminata N., 47, is a widow and the mother of 4 children, while caring for 4 other persons as well. Her business is selling cloth. This loan will permit her to buy "bazin" (damask) which has been dyed, and also Khartoum (a sort of cloth) and meulfeu (a voile for turbans) so as to bolster her business and improve living conditions for her family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: selling dyed cloth of various sorts

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana T., 35, is married with three children. She has five years of experience in her pig-raising business. She sells to the general public six days per week and expects her weekly net cash flow to be 150 Tala. She has no previous loan with SPBD.

SPBD loans are Susana’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase coconuts in bulk, old tyres for storing water, wire for fencing and iron roofing for sheltering the pigs

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia is 45 years old and is a married woman with four children, two of whom are currently schooling. She is a very hardworking woman and her children love her.

Cecilia has been trading for the last seven years and it is out of her income from this that she takes care of her children. She trades cereals such maize, groundnuts (peanuts), beans and other food items. She buys these crops directly from the farmers at a relatively low price. This, she said, protects her from middlemen who sell to her at a higher price.

Cecilia sells at the local market in the town where she lives with her family and also treks with some of her goods to nearby markets to sell as well. She also says that she wants to use the loan to buy the goods in bulk so that she can distribute to a larger number of customers.

loans.use: To buy cereals in bulk

loans.name: Lotu

texts.en:
Lotu K. is a 54-year-old man living in the town of Eva 3. He is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Lotu owns and operates a business making and selling food.  The main source of income for the business comes from selling baked goods in the local community. Lotu has been engaged in this business for more than six years and earns approximately 250 WST a month from these activities.

In 2006, Lotu joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lotu has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2250 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Lotu is now requesting a new loan of 1000 WST, which will also be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the fifth loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD.  Lotu plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business  to improve/expand his business.

About SPBD

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self-esteem.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en:
Letecia M. is from the village of San Isidro, Talakag Bukidnon. She is 32 years old. Letecia is separated from her spouse and has two young children. To make a living, Letecia owns and operates a business making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Letecia has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Letecia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Letecia is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Letecia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Yudith Antonieta

texts.es:
La señora Antonieta es socia del Banco Comunal “Santa Rosa de Lima”  que esta ubicado en el distrito de J., Provincia de Chucuito, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 24 años de edad, estado civil soltera sin hijos, educación superior Tecnológico agropecuario, vive en Chacachaca  Buena Vista.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace 4 años,  su préstamo inicial fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, el mismo que lo invirtió comprando ganado ovino.

En este momento ella solicito un préstamo de S/. 1500.00 Nuevos soles, para la compra de combustible que es el actual negocio de la Sra. Antonieta y comenta que le va muy bien.

Su sueño es poner un grifo en su lugar de venta.

A ella le gustan las charlas y las orientaciones.

loans.use: Para la compra de combustible.

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma is from the village of Bonfal Proper, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. Due to difficulties in her life, she was not able to pursue her college education. She then started to work to help her parents earn a living. She is married to Willie and they have not yet been blessed with a child.

Thelma’s husband works as a security guard in one of the banks in Nueva Vizcaya while Thelma manages their sari-sari store (village store) at home. She is asking to borrow financial capital to be added to her revolving capital in her store. She believes that PHP 20,000 will be of big help in the expansion of her store. She will utilize the amount to acquire different grocery items, cases of soft drinks and frozen foods at Solano Public Market that she will retail in her store.

The average income she earns every month amounts to PHP 5,000 which she uses as rolling capital. She aims to earn a higher income so that she is able to save for future emergencies in their lives. She believes that, someday, she will be able to improve her business by means of patience, hard work and the continuous support of Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Odera Douglas

texts.en: Douglas is married to Hadijah and they have no children yet. Douglas has been in the business of selling men’s clothing for two years. His business is situated near a university, so his clients are mainly students and other residents within the area. Douglas was introduced to KADET through existing clients and he has no previous credit history. His loan will be used to purchase additional stock: trousers and shirts. With the extra profits, Douglas intends to open a butchery to diversify his work. Douglas believes he is hardworking and hopes to own a boutique. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Zaur

texts.en: Zaur was born in 1970 and lives in the Fuzuli region. He is married and has two children. Zaur operates a car repair business, and has been engaged in the business for five years. Now, he is requesting a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy spare parts to improve and expand his business.

loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
Angelina P. owns a sari-sari (retail) store in Norala, South Cotabato.  She is 58 years old and married to William P..  They have five children to support. Their eldest child is 32 years old. They wish to expand their business but have limited capital.  

She heard about Community Economic Ventures, Inc., which offers financial assistance with low interest. She joined in November of 2007.  Now she would like to request a loan of 16,000 PHP to continually support her business and help sustain her family.

loans.use: Groceries

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Leticia D. C. lives and does business in Baclaran - a commercial district between the cities of Paranaque and Pasay City. She is 55 years old and lives with her two children.

Leticia owns and manages a bakery which is open to customers twenty-four hours a day (24/7). She also has a general store where she sells banana cue and coconuts. She opened her bakery a few years ago with only an assistant working at the oven. Now her bakery employs nine bakers who rotate as store attendants as well. She earns at least P30,000 a day from the combined operations of the bakery and the general store.

She has just finished repaying her previous loan with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative. The easy-to-pay and low-interest loans provided by the cooperative allow her to purchase bakery supplies and store merchandise in bulk amounts, saving her a lot of time and money. She has currently applied for a new loan in the amount of P48,000 to use as additional capital for her businesses.

Leticia believes that education would be the best gift she could give her children, so she works hard to better improve her businesses. She finds fulfillment in that from her profits and savings, she is able to send her children to reputable schools.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase bakery supplies and other merchandise for a general store

loans.name: Sophia Wahito

texts.en:
For five years, Sophia has owned a business selling polyethylene bags and eggs to residents within a busy residential area of Nairobi. She has one employee in her business.  Her main business challenge is poor road infrastructure during rainy periods. 

She will use proceeds of $675 to restock eggs and polyethylene bags.  Sophia's goal in life is to own a wholesale shop and educate her four-year-old son.  She is married and describes herself as hardworking and humble.

loans.use: To increase stock of polyethylene bags and eggs

loans.name: Hazel

texts.es: La señora Hazel G. M. tiene 54 años de edad habita en el barrio Jose dolores Estrada es madre soltera y tiene 4 hijos, uno de los es guarda de seguridad, la otra es enfermera y los otros dos son obreros, el mayor logro de ella sería el poder terminar realizar mejoras en su casa y acondicionar un cuarto de alquiler, ella se dedica a la venta de recargas telefónicas y al arrendamiento de cuartos tiene 26 años de dedicarse al alquiler de cuartos, tiene planes para el futura de realizar mejoras en las condiciones de infraestructura que se encuentra su casa con esto lograría mayores ingresos y podría instalar una tienda pero para este fin solicito un préstamo con el objetivo de comprar zapatos y artículos plásticos para aprovechar la temporada navideña. Este préstamo le traería mayores ingresos económicos que se traducirían a un mejor nivel de vida para toda la familia G..
texts.en:
Mrs. Hazel G. M. is 54 years old and lives in the José Dolores Estrada neighborhood. She is a single mother of 4 children. One is a security guard, the other is a nurse and two are laborers. Her greatest achievement would be to finish improvements on her house and fix up a room to rent. She works selling pre-paid phone cards and renting rooms. She has been renting rooms for 26 years. She has plans for the future to improve the infrastructure conditions where her house is. She would obtain a larger income and could install a store. But she applied for this loan with the aim of buying shoes and plastic goods to take advantage of the Christmas season. This loan will bring her a larger income which would translate to a better level of living for the whole G. family.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Haynes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothes, shoes and plastic goods

loans.name: Petimani

texts.en:
Petimani E. is 29 and single with no children.  She is starting a business venture, selling pancakes (fried flour pancakes flavored with lemon or coconut jam).  Petimani needs a loan of WST $1000 to buy flour, flavoring, sugar, and plastic bags.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 195 tala or US $81 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2009, Petimani joined SPBD.    This is her 1st loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Petimani's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Petimani E. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.5 out of 3
Level of Education:                              1.89 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         1.66 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2.1 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to buy flour, flavoring, sugar, and plastic bags

loans.name: Zinatou

texts.fr: Née en 1982, T. Zinatou réside depuis six ans à Lokokokoumè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin.  Mariée à IBRAHIM Zacharie, un chauffeur, Zinatou est mère de deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Le couple vit avec ses enfants. Zinatou et son mari se partagent ensemble les charges de la famille. Pour participer aux dépenses familiales, Zinatou exerce comme activité principale la vente de maïs et de riz, et parallèlement à cela, la vente de savon. C’est à Kandi dans le nord du Bénin que Zinatou se ravitaille. Zinatou vend ses produits à Abattoir, un quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Zinatou n’a jamais fréquenté l’école mais a déjà bénéficié de 2 crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a tous bien remboursés.  Zinatou souhaite diversifier ses activités mais ne dispose pas suffisamment de moyens financiers pour y arriver. C’est la raison pour laquelle Zinatou sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Zinatou T., born in 1982, has been living in Lokokoumè, in Sèmè-Podji in Benin, for six years. She's married to Zacharie IBRAHIM, a taxi driver. She's the mother of two school-attending children. The couple lives with their children. Zinatou and her husband support the family expenses together. To help with the family expenses, Zinatou's main business consists in selling corn and rice, as well as soaps. She gets her supplies in Kandi, in North Benin, and sells her products in Abattoir, a neighborhood in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Zinatou never attended school but already benefited from two loans from Kiva's partner, ALIDé, which were repaid without problems. She would like to diversify her business but lacks financial means to do so. This is why she's seeking her third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of corn and boxes of soaps

loans.name: Amena

texts.en: Amena is a 45-year-old woman who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon with her husband and their child. Amena has owned a housewares shop for two years. She sells dishes, trays, tea and coffee cups and more. She also sells some home decoration items like tablecloths, towels,napkins, etc. She requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her shop like cups, forks, spoons, dishes and different raw materials for her shop. When she first started her shop, she didn’t face any difficulties. Now thanks to her loan, she wants to enlarge her sales and diversify her merchandise to answer her clients' demands.  She decided on doing her business because she wanted to work and supplement her family’s income. In the future, she plans to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her shop.

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina, age 48, is the group leader of five members. She is a widow and she does not get any assistance from anyone else. She has children between the ages of 9 and 23 years old. Regina rents a one-room house where she stays with her children; she also has access to electricity and piped water. She does not care for additional family members. Normally she has one meal a day.

Regina is a tailor and she mainly tailors gomesis (Ugandan traditional wear) and school uniforms. She rents a shop where she tailors her clothes and she works six days a week. She normally sews about three gomesi's a day and her customers are mainly women and children. She normally sews materials that customers bring to her and only charges them labor costs. She has done this particular type of business for over 25 years. The problem she faces in her business is that of competition; there are many tailors around the place where she works. Also, her clients normally come seasonally, for example, when schools are opening for the term. 

Regina has been client with MCDT for more than eight years and she is servicing her 14th loan. The reason she chose to work with MCDT is because of the timely loans; she has worked with her group for eight years now. With this next loan, she wants to buy materials to resell to her customers. She will also use part of it to pay tuition for her children. Regina wants to one day be able to buy a plot of land and build a house.

loans.use: To buy more clothing materials

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy B. is from the village of Bangko, Panaon, Misamis Occidental. She is 50 years old. Mercy is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Mercy owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling clothing in the local community. Mercy has been engaged in her business for years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Mercy joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mercy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 35,000 PHP from GDMPC. Mercy is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Mercy from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it.

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en: Mohammad Hussein A. H. is 46 years old, a secondary school graduate, and a married man with seven members in his family. Two of his children  attend school in Al Nasyrat, Gaza.  Mohammad owns a grocery store for which he is requesting a loan to buy additional foodstuffs to enlarge his business and increase his profit, his ultimate goal being to raise his family's standard of living.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs for his grocey store

loans.name: Bassa Group

texts.en:
Petee D. is the head of a group of five borrowers called 'Bassa Group'.  Petee is 52 years old and could not continue her education past 9th grade. She is single and has five children whose ages range from 34-13 years. Two of her children are in university and technical college respectively while the rest are in elementary and senior high school. She also takes care of three siblings.

Petee’s involved with the sale of slippers. She buys in bulk and sells retail and she has been in this business for one year. She started her business with two dozen slippers and now has eight dozens. She is challenged by police action. She takes her goods all over Monrovia to sell.

She says many customers are attracted to her business because she sells durable and good slippers. She hopes is to get involved in another business to generate some capital to augment her present business. She plans to use her 4,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 20,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more dozens of slippers.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Petee is holding the sign.

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia 's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

 
Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=10019

loans.use: To buy more dozens of slippers

loans.name: Alan

texts.en:
Alan C., is from the village of Carangan, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. He is 38 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Alan owns and operates a piggery. He has been engaged in this kind of business for over ten years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Alan joined Kiva partner, PMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is now requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional stock of feed.
